docs.lead_paragraph: Occasional crystal meth smoker Richard Russell ambles up to a church storage garage in a Seattle alley and a recovering drug addict hands him two brand new meth pipes, no questions asked.

headline.main: Largest U.S. Needle Exchange Tries Free Meth Pipes in Seattle
headline.print_headline: Largest U.S. Needle Exchange Tries Free Meth Pipes in Seattle

docs.snippet: Occasional crystal meth smoker Richard Russell ambles up to a church storage garage in a Seattle alley and a recovering drug addict hands him two brand new meth pipes, no questions asked.

docs.lead_paragraph: A patient being monitored at a Connecticut hospital for possible Ebola after traveling in Liberia has tested negative for the deadly virus but positive for malaria, hospital officials said on Wednesday.

headline.main: Patient in Connecticut Tests Negative for Ebola
headline.print_headline: Patient in Connecticut Tests Negative for Ebola

docs.snippet: A patient being monitored at a Connecticut hospital for possible Ebola after traveling in Liberia has tested negative for the deadly virus but positive for malaria, hospital officials said on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers found that offering incentives to quit was effective, but that the chance of success was nearly doubled by setting up penalties.

headline.main: Study Asks if Carrot or Stick Can Better Help Smokers Quit
headline.print_headline: Stick Beats Carrot in Anti-Smoking Efforts, Study Says

docs.abstract: Dr Scott Halpern study in The New England Journal of Medicine finds penalizing those trying to quit smoking for failing to stay off cigarettes is more effective than offering awards for success.
docs.snippet: Researchers found that offering incentives to quit was effective, but that the chance of success was nearly doubled by setting up penalties.

docs.lead_paragraph: A patient admitted to a Connecticut hospital late on Tuesday was being monitored for possible Ebola infection after recently traveling from Liberia, a Fox News affiliate reported.

headline.main: Connecticut Patient Being Monitored for Possible Ebola
headline.print_headline: Connecticut Patient Being Monitored for Possible Ebola

docs.snippet: A patient admitted to a Connecticut hospital late on Tuesday was being monitored for possible Ebola infection after recently traveling from Liberia, a Fox News affiliate reported.

headline.main: When Doctors Help a Patient Die

docs.abstract: Physicians’ training does not prepare them for their role in medical aid in dying.
docs.snippet: Physicians’ training does not prepare them for their role in medical aid in dying.

docs.lead_paragraph: Johns Hopkins earned an A minus on global health research, an advocacy group found. But there were a lot of D’s, and even two F’s.

headline.main: University Grades Are Mixed on Research for the Poor
headline.print_headline: University Grades Are Mixed on Research for the Poor

docs.abstract: Student-led advocacy group Universities Allied for Essential Medicine issues its second ranking of American universities that receive large grants for biomedical research; rankings are based on percentage of research that focuses on diseases of poor and whether study results are affordable and accessible to scientists in poor countries.
docs.snippet: Johns Hopkins earned an A minus on global health research, an advocacy group found. But there were a lot of D’s, and even two F’s.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even after Medicare has promised to begin covering the test, it will not help everyone who’s eligible, experts warn, and will subject some to harm.

headline.main: On Medicare and Assessing the Value of Lung Cancer Screening
headline.print_headline: Assessing the Value of Lung Cancer Screening

docs.abstract: Paula Span The New Old Age column examines warnings from experts that while more than 10 million Americans will be eligible for Medicare-covered CT scan to detect lung cancer, screening will not help every eligible patient and may, in fact, cause harm; high proportion of scans will produce false positives, and some positive results that require invasive follow-up, like biopsies, present their own risks.
docs.snippet: Even after Medicare has promised to begin covering the test, it will not help everyone who’s eligible, experts warn, and will subject some to harm.

keywords.value: United States Preventive Services Task Force
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Some ingredients used in nail products have been tied to cancer, miscarriages, lung diseases and other ailments. The industry has long fought regulations.

headline.print_headline: Behind Perfect Nails, Ailing Salon Workers

docs.abstract: Research and anecdotal evidence suggest that manicurists are exposed to higher risk of serious health conditions, including cancer and respiratory and skin ailments; incidence of miscarriage and birth defects appears to be so high that women in industry warn those of child-bearing age away from profession; conclusive research on nail workers and illness remains sparse, and few regulations exist to protect those who work with chemicals on daily basis (Series: Unvarnished).
docs.snippet: Some ingredients used in nail products have been tied to cancer, miscarriages, lung diseases and other ailments. The industry has long fought regulations.

keywords.value: National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
keywords.name: organizations

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Jiha Ham, Yuhan Liu, Julie Turkewitz, Isvett Verde, Yeong-Ung Yang and Heyang Zhang, and research by Susan C. Beachy.

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization issued recommendations for naming infectious diseases, concerned about stigmas of names like swine flu and monkeypox.

headline.main: W.H.O. Urges More Care in Naming Diseases
headline.print_headline: W.H.O. Urges More Care in Naming Diseases

docs.abstract: World Health Organization releases guidelines for naming diseases, which address concerns about stigmas and misconceptions such names can create about people, animals and regions.
docs.snippet: The World Health Organization issued recommendations for naming infectious diseases, concerned about stigmas of names like swine flu and monkeypox.

docs.lead_paragraph: Inclusion on the list indicates to governments and drug companies that those medicines should be made available to poor countries at low prices.

headline.main: Hepatitis C Drugs Added to W.H.O. List of Essential Medicines
headline.print_headline: World Briefing | Science and Health; W.H.O. Adds Hepatitis C Drugs to List of Essential Medicines to Foster Access

docs.abstract: World Health Organization includes five new hepatitis C drugs on essential medicines list for first time, indication to government, regulators and companies that pricey drugs should be made available at lower prices in poorer countries.
docs.snippet: Inclusion on the list indicates to governments and drug companies that those medicines should be made available to poor countries at low prices.
